msDesc.head:
Letter from
Walter Scott
to Maria Edgeworth, Edgeworthstown, 5 July 1825. Postage stamp reading "G JY 3 1825" on address leaf

sourceDesc.bibl: In addition to our edited version, this letter was previously published in the fifth volume of The Letters of Sir Walter Scott (London: Constable, 1932-1937) and online through the Walter Scott Digital Archive.

div.p:
My letter of 2d or 3d and yours of 29th June have crossed each other
and I might dispense with writing an answer to yours espe
cially especially as it will prof cost more postage than it is worth But
I like to be as precise as possible in my appointments having
incurred much disgrace for neglecting them in my youth &
all the world knows that a prudent old age with no passions
to disturb its tranquility makes an easy amends at least
if not an ample one for the erratic courses of a wayward youth.
My friend Hartstonge may like Wisdom uplifts his
voice in the streets of Dublin But there is not the least purpose
on my part to enter under any society there. I must dine with
my sons son's
mess I suppose one day & with said Hartstonge
another if he asks me. But as I do not intend to be above
a week at Dublin in all the remaining days will be
few enough to spend with my son and daughter in a
quiet way.
Though it is unclear to which son Scott is referring here, it seems likely that he is grouping Charles and Anne together, as he mentions Walter later.

My purpose is certainly for Killarney and I am happy
to learn from your letter that I can make my route by
Edgeworths town Edgeworthstown
. I wish to Heaven you would make some
arrangements to go to Killarney with us I Walter & his

cara sposa will also make it out. Indeed I have long
tired of seeing fine places alone and though I could dispense
with the company of Lady Jocunda I find my excursions
go much better on our adays with good company by way
of sauce - once I loved my beefsteak best without pickles
and my romantic scenery was most enjoyed in solitary
blessedness

Not hearing from you about the dog I was afraid he might
be rather a troublesome present and give him away to
Chan
trey Chantrey
the sculptor who fell in high fancy with him. But
I will keep as fine a puppy for you next spring that is
if you really wish to have one for I never bring up more than
one or two puppies for want fear of weaken weakening the
dam. In fact that designed for Edgeworthtown was
put out to nurse. But I will keep a fine puppy for
you next spring.

To speak of a puppy of a different litter - I know well
that Walter is deeply infected with that sort of mauvaise
honte which make people seem uncivil when they are
only bashful and awkward. He has a holy Dread of
any thing which he considers as highly gifted with
talent and has not yet learned the simple fact that
massip clever folks are in reality the least to be found
in the shape of criticals I fancy you have
Janes Jane's
answer
for the last time I heard from her she was sitting down

with much apprehension and I dare say, after a much
careful mending of pens and folding of paper to write a
note to Miss Maria Edgeworth you are well aware of the terrors
of your own reputation. But you are an old acquaintance of
Janes Jane's
for I found almost all your works in her little
boudoir at Lochore reasonably well thumbed.
Walters Walter's
regimental
leave of absence is difficult to be obtained and keeps him
short by the halter and untill until I learn how that stands I can

form no definitive plan He has hopes
but no certainty of getting with us
to Killarney but field days and
reviews are things which interfere
much with the plans of young
officers. This is the reason that

there is such rapid promotion in these light corps considering the
times - a young man of fortune enters smitten with the delight of
ploughing the earth with a sabre and sweeping heaven with a
plume and in a few months he finds himself gone by the
severity of the discipline exit Dandy and there is a step in
the regiment
div.closer:
I have little to add except kindest love to Mrs
Edge
worth Edgeworth
Harriet and all friends known and unknown - We
must manage to see Mr W. Edgeworth I regret to say our limited
stay gives us no hope of seeing my charming young friend Mrs Fox
Lane or making her husbands acquaintance. Lady Scott begs
kind love always yours with equal respect & sincerity
Walter Scott
